pageContext.desc: Teacher, principal, and preacher's wife in New York, New Hampshire, and Michigan.

pages.transcription:
cross-written across top:
Lizzie sends
love and says
that she would
like a letter too.
She forgot to
pack Dr.  [illegible]
recipe in her
last letter, but
says she will
send it to
Aunt Mary 
at [Remsen?}
268 West St. North
Hillsdale, Mich: July 15, 1893
My dear Aunt Anna:
We were so very
glad to get your good letter day be-
fore yesterday. The postman went 
right by at first and said he had
nothing for us but he came back 
in a few minutes with the letter
raging that he had forgotten it.
I return Mrs. Jones' letter, which
I am very much obliged to you 
for getting for me and to - Eddie 
for letting me read. What a
dear, sweet soul she is! I am
so sorry she has business troubles
and can imagine [just?] how she 
deprives herself in order to help
that little grand-daughter. She 
evidently wishes that she could

release us from our note, when we
ought really to be paying back all
that she let us have.

    I am very glad that she doesn't

let Eddie pay back any that he had.

 We are all quite wilted and nearly

melted by the weather this week.

I hope you have ^not the conscience to

be chilly these days. If you have,
I can boast over you for I have
even laid aside my inseparable
companion the faithful old red
shawl.Mrs Davis and Ida even
in last night and they facetiously
asked me if I had to have a
fire, these days Lizzie heartlessly
remarked that I managed to get
along with the kitchen fire.
Well, you and I are fellow sufferers
in this cold and cruel world .We
can sympathize with each other and
exchange shiver for shiver can't we?

 Many thanks for the Pulsatilla. I was

not suffering for it. but thought I

would like to have it on hand
Lizzie did not have any, but there
was enough in the little package
for us both. The Aldriches are
living on Prof. Gurney's house now, 
while they are away for the summer

 Bennie came over last night

and invited Eva and me down
there. We had a nice little visit,
and some ice-cream. They were much
surprised to hear of Eddie's marriage.

 I attended Nettie Dunn's wedding

last Wednesday night There was
a large company there, mostly
people from College Hill. Nettie
looked very sweet in white
silk. and the green was nice-
looking. Prof. Dunn performed
the ceremony, and did it in his
happiest vein. There were a
great many very useful and
beautiful presents. Holden sent down
a ["Soo"?] souvenir spoon for me to
take. She had three dozen solid silver

tea-spoons, besides several souvenir
and berry spoons.

    I expect to take the steamer for

home, Monday evening, July 24th
Yes see my visit is "long-drawn-
out" but both of my physicians
have advised it, Dr. Moore thinks
I ought to stay all summer. but
Holden thinks he has lived alone
about as long as he can. I have
been improving very fast since I
went to see Dr. Andrews.

I wish Aunt Mary could have made

John and Azia a little visit. It was
nice she caught a glimpse of him.
We will write to her soon. I think
that John and Azia are planning
to go home with me. I shall be very
glad of their company. We shall
hope to hear from you after.

 Please give my love to Eddie, Ella

and the children. and accept a
large share for your precious self.

            Very lovingly,    Hattie

Sault Ste-Marie Michigan
                           September 11th . 1893

My Dear Aunt Anna:

                 It seems a

long, long time since we have heard
from you. Very likely it is my
own fault but that, you know,
doesn't make it any easier to
bear. We have been at home now
nearly seven weeks. The first four
weeks, John and Azia and Clarence
spent with us. Then soon after they
left, we all went down the river
about thirty miles to Sailor's
Encampment to spend a couple
of weeks with the Johnston girls,
of whom I told you, their Indian
descent etc. They have a little
shanty of two rooms right near
the river and also a "lodge"
made of hemlock and birch bark

The shanty was given up to us
at night, while the girls occupied
the lodge, and their father and 
mother and brother occupied
tents.Their brother, "Howard"
has charge of the range lights
along the river for which he re -
ceives fifty dollars a month,
as long as the boats are running
It was pleasant being in sight
of the river, where we saw so
many large steamers and barges
constantly passing. Holden count
ed thirty-six one day, and didn't
see nearly all them. He and Eva
went fishing several time
and Eva proved to be the best
fisherman. She caught seventeen
perch one day, while Holden only 
caught one. Eva got a large
pike on her hook one day, but 
when they tried to get it into
the boat, it broke the line, and

carried off hook sinkers and all.
They have no regular services
on the Island, so Holden preached 
both Sunday evenings that we 
were there. I had a hard cold 
all the time I was there, and 
was sick abed twice, with chills 
and fever. We came back sooner 
than we expected on this account.
I don't know what I should 
have done if I had not had 
that dose of medicine you [illegible] 
up for me, for there was no 
doctor within reach. These little 
pellets soon relieved me however,  
and I think my faith was 
strengthened a good deal, as 
well as my body. I had to 
laugh at Miss Johnston [illegible] 
(in my sleeve), for she took ^two of 
those smallest pellets of Arsenicum, 
just to see how it tasted, and 
she said it made her feel sick 
all night.

Since we came home, I have been feeling
a good deal better, thought my cold
and cough still trouble me.
My stay at Hillsdale did me so 
much good. I didn't feel like the 
same person when I came back. 
I have a good girl in the kitchen 
now, so hope to keep from get
ting so run down again.
I wonder if Aunt Mary is beginning
to think about coming back from
the east, and what you are
planning to do this fall and
winter. I hope you will stay in
the state, for you are so near and 
dear to us we want you within
visiting distance! We hope to 
be nearer you all, sometime.
We all [join?] in very much love
to you, and to Eddie and family
Eva is planning to answer
[Jaidee's?] dear little letter, before
long. Very lovingly, as ever,
Hattie

[Written across the top:]
year. We regret
it very much but
Frank is obliged
to get there as soon
as possible on ac
count of his business
and it is considera-
ble cheaper going
that way. We hate
to lose them terribly,
especially the Baby
Claire but it can't
be helped. I wish you
would write before
we start if you can.
Give a great deal of
love to all, and take
a long [slaze?] for your
self_as ever lovingly-Hattie

Hillsdale, Michigan
June 24th, 18[76?]
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                  I believe I am

owing you a letter, am I not? At any
rate it is time I was, so I guess I will
write and give you a chance to make
me. It is over a week now since Com-
mencement, but I don't seem to get
much rested. Perhaps I am "constitu-
tionally tired", but I guess I shall
feel better after our journey we are
thinking of making. And I must tell
you about Utah. We expect to leave
here the tenth of July and go first
to Washington, where we shall stop
a few days, and then go to Philadelphia

and spend one or two weeks there,
then to New York city for a day or
two, and then [triple underlined] to Remsen [underlined], which
I think will be nicest of all.
So we shall see you about the 
last of July. We are going with a 
family, Mr. Winson's people, and
some other, and expect to enjoy
it very much. Father thinks the
journey will do mother and me
good, and I think a good deal the
same myself! Indeed, I don't know
but I was the first one who sug-
gested it!--However I think dear
old Remsen will be the crowning
point of all and I expect to look
forward to that with longing and
almost impatience, through the weeks
spent at other places. I want to
gain ten pounds while I am gone

for I only weigh ninety pounds now
and I have weighed ninety-nine, and
I was the lightest one in our class.
My greatest ambition is to weigh a
hundred and ten, but I never ex-
pect to attain to that. It is well
to have high aims in life though_
You wouldn't guess that I was an
Alumna of Hillsdale College, and
a "B.S.", to read such nonsense,
would you? But actually, I didn't
see any difference, when I came down
from the stage after speaking my
little piece and receiving my diplo-
ma, I didn't feel a bit metamor-
phosed into anything, or anybody
very wise or big, but just the same
little goose I always was. I don't 
think graduating is a farce though
by any means, I got four bouquets.

Mother wants me to take my exercises with
me and inflict them on you. I don't know
though, I like you pretty well and I haven't
hardly the heart too [second o crossed out]. Perhaps if you want
to you can buy me off with onions after
I get there.     Frank came out to see
me graduate after all. He couldn't stay
away when the time came, but I shall
want to see him just as much at Rem-
sen for he only staid here three days
as he had to go back on account of
an old yearly meeting of his.
I do hope they will have a camp
meeting at [Trenton?] while we are there,
so we can go. Do you suppose Aunt
Mary can come home while we are
there? I hope so. Perhaps she can come
with us right from New York. How nice
that would be. Frank and Lizzie start
for Lewiston Wednesday. They go through
Canada, so they will not be able to visit

[written across the top]: none sure [underlined], and when
I do write I
at least have
the pleasure of
expecting an an-
swer, whether it
comes or not.
We all sympa-
thize very much
with Grandma, I do
hope she will be
more comfortable
soon-   Aren't you
all tired of the cold
weather? Michigan
is the state for me!
With much love to all,
and expecially yours lovingly,
Hattie
Hillsdale, Michigan,
January [?], 1877_
My Dear Aunt Jennie:_

                                      I have a letter

commenced to you in my writing desk, but {struck through]
dated December 28th, but I can't finish
it for the last sentence written is only
just begun and I can't think for my
life what it was I was going to say!
So you see I have made a new start.
Whether I am able to finish ths with
out interruption, I do not know now as
well as you will when you receive it.

    The only thing of importance that I

said in the unfinished sheet was that
I could not tell how it happened that
I had left your last letter so long un
answered, and come to consider it, that
was not of much importance either, for
it would be hard for anyone to tell

how I could neglect such a super extra
good letter. I expected when I received
it to answer it immediately, and 
perhaps that was the very reason why I 
didn't, for father says "the unexpected
always takes place".  But then you 
know I have been sick too, and the
others have written so often that I
have thought I could send a little
"anytime", and I am beginning to learn
that "anytime" most generally means
"never".  Those things that are in the
most danger of never being accomplish
ed are such as can be done "anytime",
don't you think so? We are all appall-
ed just now by the news of that terrible
railroad disaster in Ohio. How pecu-
liarly sad seems the death of so widely
renowned a man as P.P. Bliss, with
all his family, and yet how few doubt
less, were as well prepared as they.

    Two young ladies here in College re

ceived word yesterday that their father

was on the ill-fated train, coming to
spend New Year's with them.

    Many are still in suspence as to

whether they have lost friends or not.,
it seems dreadful to think of.

                          I have been meaning to

write to some of you ever since Aunt
Sarah and Uncle Will came out, to
influence you to send them a letter
at least every other day. At first
they couldn't seem reconciled to not
receive one every mail and if wrung
my heart to see them disappointed so
often, but now I think they are con-
tented if two[underline]) come every[underlined] other[underlined] day[underlined]. Now
don't think I am writing this to tease
them!     I often wonder if their
letters seem as few and far between
to you, as yours do here. It seems
strange the mails are so irregular, and
play such tricks with the letter's.

    We have made us a new game

that we have lots of fun playing. I think

John[something struck through] Eddie would like it. Johnnie
wrote five Alphabets on (five times twenty
six) squares of pasteboard, putting each
letter on both sides of the square, and
this we mix them all up and each one
selects letters for any word he thinks
of, then disarrange them and change.
One wouldn't think it would be so
difficult to tell what word was in
tended when all the letters are there.
Do you like such ways of passing an
evening occasionally?  I suppose Aunt
Sarah wrote you about the Christmas
Tree at the church, we went to see.
It was the first (and only) festival of
its kind I have attended in Hillsdale.

  Don't you think Aunt Anna better

ask me directly what makes me so
still instead of making roundabout
inquiries, especially when she owes
me a letter?  However I am not going
to keep still any longer, if doesn't pay.
for when I write no letters I receive

[written across the top]:
use of my molasses
than you do!
The idea of try-
ing to black the 
stove with it
You must have
imagined the fumes[underlined]
would reach Uncle
Will and help
his Asthma. Per
haps that was[underlined] it
I believe he was a
little better about
that time!
There! There! Shut up
the stove! I am[underlined] go
ing to close! Very
hastily, but as ever
lovingly - Hattie
Hillsdale, Michigan
January 20th, 1877
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                 I am completely

overwhelmed with gratitute and astonish
ment at your promptness in answering my
letter. And so you see I am hastening to
write again lest you may all feel kind
of lost in knowing that you are not ow-
inw me a letter. It would be an unheard
of state of things for none of you to be
owing me, wouldn't it!  I have been
thinking seriously since yesterday of chal-
lenging Aunt Mary to a poetry[underlined] match[underlined].
I know I could write more than four
lines if I got such an inspiration as
she evidently had. If I was the Muse
of Poetry I wouldn't visit her again
unless she could pay me better than
that for my trouble. But of course her

machine may have broken after such
a strain. Tell her I think she ought
to be careful about publishing this until
she gets a copyright for it might lead
to a dispute as to the authorship of
it. If Longfellow or Bryant should
claim it there might be difficulty in
convincing the world that it came from
an (as yet) obscure and unknown
poet. In such a case I think I should
feel it my duty to come forward and
tell the world frankly that I wrote
it. That wouldn't be true, of course, but
it would be heroic, now wouldn't it,
to admit that you wrote such a thing!
Well I'll have Aunt Mary sending me
some [quieting?] powders that aren't all
sugar if I say much more. So I will
continue my letter to you, I guess.
I must confess that Johnnie writes very
few letters except to Ohio, but what
can the poor fellow do with a letter
coming an average every other day

and no one to answer them but
himself! Uncle Will and I have
repeatedly offered our services both
in noting the contents and returning
answers to the letters but so blind
is he to his own interests that he rejects
our offers every time. I hardly know
what to tell you of the person who so
occupies his attention, for I fear I
may be repeating what you have al
ready heard from other sources.
But I fancy if Aunt Sarah could
be persuaded to remain here until
spring she would have the pleasure
of receiving another neice into the family.
It will be nice for me to have a 
sister again, will it not! Ah, but
no one can fill little Lizzie's place!

    Oh I do hope you and Aunt Anna

and Grandma will come and make
us a good long visit next summer.
It would be perfectly delightful!

And I would show you what a nice
little housekeeper I shall be by that time!
Bring John Eddie along too, and then
perhaps I can go through my cook-book
in order, as I have so often wished to
do. It will be so nice to have some
one to eat up the things when I don't
have very good luck.  There, I 
didn't mean to scare anybody. Tell
John Eddie to come and I won't do
any such barbarous thing. It was
horrid of me to think of it. We shall
have the cream of the land,_churned,_
that will be the nicest kind or butter-
milk you see. But I believe my
letter is really rising above its usual
height of absurdity, and I must close
before you get quite to the [point?] of using
my letter[struck through] ^it as a persuader to the fire.
I made some delicious gingersnaps yes-
terday. Won't you have one? Uncle Will
ate the biggest one there was and then
said they weren't good. Can you imagine
my emotions?--You see I make a better

[embossed rose at top of page]

         Hillsdale, Febr^uary 3rd, 1877

My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                Your last letter

created quite a stir in our usually quiet
household. I mean your last letter to
me. It made us all laugh heartily at
Johnnie's expense. I think many such
letters would exasperate him into turn
ing his attention in your direction. This
one would doubtless at any other time
than within four weeks of his wedding.

    Won't it be nice for me to have a

sister again? I expect it will be just
like Johnnie to monopolize her though

don't you? He has just come from
town and brought the second number
of [Moody and Sankey's--struck through] P. P. Bliss and Sankey's Hymn Book. One
piece in it "The Changing Bells of Time" I 
heard sung most beautifully by an
Evangelist who was here [last--struck through] the first
part of this week. His name is Spencer
and he has the richest sweetest voice
nearly that I ever heard. The meetings
here continue to be very interesting.
Thirty arose for prayers at one time.
Many are young people, and some quite
advanced in life.

    Tell Aunt Sarah that Mr. Childs is

selling all his goods at a reduced
rate, thouh they are not injured in
the least by smoke or anything else.

I got mother some seventy-five cent
flannel for sixty cents, so you see
the reduction isn't very much though it
is worth[underlined] accepting[underlined].  Tell Uncle Will
that Mr. [Goolly's?] wife is in here now and
she is as cool[underlined] as he, besides being decid-
edly more talkative and it's enough to
drive anyone frantic who is trying to
write a sensible[underlined] letter, as you
know mine always are! I must
tell you how smart mother and I were
this morning. We had breakfast at
half past seven and after that we
cleared up the breakfast dishes, filled
the lamps, made the beds, put the
chicken on to boil, cooked some
squash and made five large pies

before ten o'clock. Then after that
I made biscuitts[second t struck through] and got dinner.
Mother has been clear out to the gate
this afternoon. I think we are getting
along realy nicely. There is a new pro-
prietor in the Laundry here now and
we get our clothes more regularly than
we did. One of the Professors here in 
College, Mr. Fisk, has been obliged to
go to his old home in New Hampshire
on account of his health. We went Tues
day, so if Uncle Will had only waited
one day he might have had some of 
most "original" company he ever met.
Can't you and Aunt Anna come out
at Commencement time? I wish you
could. Please write soon. Lovingly, Hattie

[cross-written across top]:
our weeks seem to
be nowadays.
Mary is real
good help. She
does our washing
and ironing now.
You don't know
how much I want
to see you all or
even any of you.
Sometimes it seems
as though I must.
I know so little and
have so many per-
plexities, and nobody
to go to. Please
write when you can
Auntie Dear.
Ever Lovingly, Hattie.

                       Hillsdale, June [20th?] 1877

My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                 Nothing but the

hurry and complete occupation of Com
mencement week could have kept me
from writing and acknowledging those
beautiful forgetmenots the day I re-
ceived them. They came Wednesday
morning, just the right time, and I
put them down cellar in water im-
mediately and they revived and be-
came as sweet and fresh as could
be desired. I showed them to the lady
at the greenhouse and she said they
were entirely different from any she
ever saw. They were admired by all
who saw them and I am most obliged

for your kindness than I can tell you.
I fear though that you robbed your-
selves, I had no idea of your sending
so many. I must tell you about
those plants you sent me when you
first went back too. The forget-
menot, daisy, white pansy, and 
that fine green vine with a yellow
flower, are all in blossom and
growing like everything. Our flower-
seeds didn't come up very well so
we are all the gladder of those lit-
tle plants. Those plants that you
rooted from [slips?] while here are
nearly all living and doing well.
Both my vines are running up
on trellis and [illegible] as fast as
ever they can, and the begonia is
flourishing finely. You mustnt
think that this dreadful writing is
from my gold pen Aunt Jennie.

I am writing with a steel pen this
morning because I am in a tearing
hurry and am afraid of hurting the
gold one. I do not mean to break
that as I did my other. Do you know
I just finished my black cambric
dress about a week ago. Wasn't I
slow?  But there were so many things
to hinder me. It looks just as pretty
as can be. Made in a [Lolasaise?] and
trimmed with fine knife pleating. I
cut it and all. Did you get to [South?]
Hadley? Or are you going, or are you
there now? I have forgotten the time
of the reunion. You know the reunions
here are in '80, and one of the A-
lumni who came back to Com-
mencement made me promise
that if neither of us were married
then I would attend the reunion
[letter struck out] suffer with him. Only think of

[of--struck through] making such an engagement three
years beforehand. He is Principal
of a High School in an Ohio city,
and expects to go to Europe next
year. I am going to the lake with
him this afternoon, and it will be
a perfect time to be on the water
if it continues as pleasant as now.
Are you as much afraid of these
row-boats as Uncle Will, or do
you enjoy such fun as much as
I? We are going to commence can-
ning strawberries today and expect
to have these nearly every day this
week. Then a carpenter is coming
tomorrow to make those two back
chambers into one and we have
trunks and boxes and feather-
beds and everything else (you re-
member) to take care of. So you
see it will be a busy week as all

[cross-written across top]:
drowned once-
I should like
to go every week
and learn to
row. Tell Uncle 
Will when he gets
a farm he must
remember and
have a pond in
the middle
of it and
then I will
come and
see him.
But I must close
and go do something
more profitable[underlined]
Love to all

          from,
                Hattie

Hillsdale, July 4th, 1877
Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                        Here it is only nine

o'clock in the morning and we have the
work all done up until it is time to
get dinner, and I have practiced my
music for today, and all because
we got up so early. You see being the
"glorious Fourth" we couldn't sleep
for the bells and guns and crackers.
Johnnie fired crackers through the 
blinds of their chamber window be-
fore any of us were up, and then he
tied some on the end of a pole and 
let them off close by my window.
Wasn't that dignified proceeding,
for a College Professor?!

I remember very well that it isn't
my turn to write you Aunt Jennie,
but it seems so long since we have
heard from Remsen that I feel im
pelled to stir you up a little and
find out if you are all asleep.
We wrote to Aunt Mary yesterday.
I suppose she will be in New York
all summer, will she not?
Azia expects to go to Ohio next
week to visit her friends. She
will stay three or four weeks and then
Johnnie wil go for her. I think I 
shall stay at home like a good girl
most of the summer and keep my
fun for next year. Father and I are
planning for a nice trip then if
everything goes right. We have just
been loving those two small back
chambers made into one and John
nie and Azia are going to love

that and we shall fix up the front
room for a spare chamber. So
any time after the middle of July
we shall be ready to receive guests.
Now is the time to speak for accom
modations! How many shall I 
enter from [Steuben?]? I have been
getting me some cloth for a white
overdress. It is quite pretty and I 
cut and made the overskirt yes-
terday with the exception of the trim-
ming which will be Hamburg edge.
You see I am getting smart, it does
not take me six months to ^finish any-
thing, any more. Mary has gone home
to spend the Fourth, went last
night and will be back tonight.
She does our washing and ironing
now and is real faithful about the
work. Did you go to your class re-
union as you thought of? We had

a letter from Frank and Lizzie the
other day saying that they thought come
of coming out at Christmas to 
spend the Holidays with us. Would-
n't it be lovely if they could?
Darling little Claire said that she
was writing to her "dear, good, dear,
sweet, Auntie Hattie". But they
didn't send the letter. I thought it
was too bad. Frank said she im-
proved a great deal while she was
out here. Father and I, Johnnie and
Azia, and Professor Haynes and his 
wife all went down to Bawbeese
Lake last week and spent the after-
noon. We took our baskets of good
things with us and had our supper
in the grove. Father didn't like to 
go on the [?] but the rest of
us went in a round boat too.
I have been down this a num-
ber of times lately and haven't been

[cross-written across top]:
It makes me very
sad to think of
your home bereft
as ours is of a pre
cious mother. But
each loss draws us
nearer to each other
and nearer to our
Heavenly Father.

    We shall none of us

have many more part
ings for we shall each
be called ourselves. 
If I can only be as well
prepared as you all are
I shall not dread the
summons.

                                Hillsdale, Michigan
                                                   March 23rd, 1878

Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                             Your letters were

very gladly received yesterday and I am
sorry that I must answer in such a
hurry, but father wants to take [this?] to
the office at ten and so I have only about
half an hour to write in. I have been
pretty closely occupied this week as there
has been a musical convention held
in town and I have attended every eve-
ning, and either morning or afternoon
of each day. I went three times the 
first day but found that it was too
much for me. Professor L. O. Emerson
of Boston conducted it, and last even
ing we closed with a concert which went

off very nicely. Professor Emerson as you
know is a great composer of music and
he gave us excellent instructions, dwelling
particularly upon the importance, in sing-
ing, of light and shade, proper expression,
and the distinct articulation of words.

    I went into Court one afternoon this week

for the first time in my life. There were
several ladies in, and although the case
was not particularly interesting, one of
a chattel mortage, I enjoyed it being so
new to me.

    Has Maggie's school commenced yet?

I should ^think she would enjoy it if it is not
too hard for her. I do hope we can see you
all this summer, but I suppose it is not
at all certain, we can tell but little
about the future.  Dear Grandma was
very, very kind to remember us children
so and her loving thoughtfulness for us
touches be very much. She and dear
mother were just alike in thinking and

caring for each one. But it doesn't
seem right for me to take my share for
I do not need it and I fear you do.

    If I had it I should never use it

until I came in absolute need of it
for it would seem like something sacred
to me and too precious to spend un-
less from real necessity. But you have
not much, and all your expenses to
bear, and you may really need it, and
so Auntie dear, if there is such a possi-
bility I shall be glad to relinquish all
claim to mine and let you Auntie have
it. You have always been kind and gener-
ous to others in the largest hearted way,
and now you ought to think of your-
selves as I believe you never did yet.

    But father is going and I must close.

I hope you will all be very careful and
not work or worry yourselves ill.

    With a heart full of love to each one

I am as ever, Your Loving,

                                      Hattie

Hilledale, May 31st, 1878
My Dear Auntie,
As it is not my turn to write to anybody I thought that I would heat coals of fire promiscuously and write to everybody. You Remses people are splendid correspondents when you correspond, but when you don't you're horrid. Now you can take that compliment for just what it is worth as I shall not charge anything for it. We have been wondering if Eddie received the Latin books that Johnnie sent him. He happened to have duplicates, so he could send them as well as not. I hope we shall decide about our journey before long, but we are still undecided whether to go by Canada or through Utica. I very
(top of page)
of? Reses. But I think you said there were two of that name. Father is waiting to take this to the office so i must send a blank page this time. You may fill it out in? imagination with all  the loving things I would like to say. With much love to each and all,
Hattie
much prefer the latter, but they have offered a discount to the Faculty on the other road.

do it well, even if she has to take the time out of her sleeping house and sacrifice her health.
We are having beautiful weather now, just cool enough to be comfortable. I have been having a dressmaker here at the house to sew for me for the last five days. She helped me a great deal, and made the least extra work and trouble of anyone that I ever had. We have to keep pretty busy with our regular house-work and getting ready for our journey, and Azia being in school and all. An Irish woman who helped us clean house has sent her little girl up to help us before school in the morning for the past week or two. I find a little assistance a great help where there are so many staps to be taken. Is John Griffiths' daughter Jennie married? There was a notice of a Jennie Griffiths marriage in a paper not long ago and she was

it. Excuse this short note for I must write a few words to dear Aunt Sarah.
Lovingly--
Hattie
previous text written sideways; main text follows
Hillsdale, Michigan
May 23rd, 1879.
Dear Aunt Jennie:-
Father received a letter from Uncle William this morning enclosing these pictures and giving the following information in regard to them.
"John H. Lowell &Co. 21 Exchange Place, are Steel plate engravers and herewith I send you one of their late engravings of ex-Gov. Onslow Stearns of N. H. lately deceased. I knew Mr. Stearns and this is a good picture of him. I got it from

them this A M and their lowest price is $125.00 each flate, and $1.50 fer 100 engravings or pictures.
I also send you a lithographic picture, from the ils Lartier who got out their of Eld. John Steviner of Biddeford Me. Their prices are $20.00 each for Portraits, and $3.00 per hundred copies. If you order from either party you should send the? best picture you have for them to copy from. "
He also says that he cut this picture tow inches narrower, and two inches shorter than they were made, for convenience in mailing.
Just as I finished writing this last sentence father came in with his sad tidings from Remsen?.  It is so su? cannot realize

Vertical writing in top margin
ill. I feel very anxious about her. He didn't write any particulars only that she was very weak, and able to sit up but a moment at a time. My eyes still trouble me, but otherwise I am very well. Write soon please -- Love to? each of you from, Hattie
Horizontal writing
Hillsdale, October, 17th, 80.
Dear Aunt Jennie:
Your letter was very gladly received about a week ago, and your postal? yesterday. We were considerably surprised to hear of Mife Williams arrival to this country. I trust that she will be more favorably impressed than was Uncle Rath.?, with the country and people. I know she will like her first cousins, anyway, whether she does the rest of the Americans or not. I have had some very pleasant letters from her, and should like very much to become acquainted. Do you think it would be improper, or unadvisable, considering all circumstances, to write her to visit us?

Please tell me just what you think, for I am in considerable perplexity about it, and want your advice. You know I should enjoy a visit from her very much, but it might be embarrassing to other parties, and I am at a loss to know whether I should be doing the wrong thing to ask her or not. Please consider this confidential, Aunt Jennie, Dear, and give me your opinion. If you think it would be proper for me to write her to visit us, please give me her address. I don't want to shock her ideas of propriety at all, but I should like to see her very much. Azia is going to leave us this week, and father and I will find our family pretty small. We have a young lady working for her board, so there will be three of us. I believe I haven't written to you since Johnnie left Cleveland. He is at Bay City, in the state, now. He had a good opportunity to buy
out a gentleman's furnishings establishment, and so gave up her book trade. He?  far? laid down partly for [[

one of the students room here, and let them pay for their rent so. But he spoke the other night of John Eddie, and wondered if he wouldn't like to come out and enter College, and so board with us and help him about these things. He would be so much company for us we should enjoy it, and perhaps we could help each other in that way. Father has a scholarship, so he wouldn't have to pay any tuition only for incidentals (two or three dollars a term) and he is so far along in his studies that I presume he would be able to enter the winter term as advantageously as any. What do you and he think of it? Azia's brother Charlie, her mother, and Charlie's little girl, have been visiting us the past week. Charlie is quite a prominent lawyer in Bryan, Ohio, and graduated here in '70. I had a letter from Frank, not long since, saying that Lizzie was seriously

must not use anything astringent. Father is going to the office and I must close. Please excuse a hastily written letter. Aunt Louisa's health is much better than it has been. Please remember me with much love to Miss Williams. I intend writing her soon.
With much love to each of you dear ones.
Hattie
previous text sideways; main text follows:
Hillsdale, July 21st, 1881.
Dear Aunt Jennie:-
I have neglected writing all too long, but have had so many things to try my eyes that I have put off many letters that should have been written. We were deeply shocked and pained to hear of Uncle Lewis' death, the news of which came so unexpectedly. The circle of loved ones in the other Home, will soon out-number those of us left here. How will Aunt Jane and my dear cousins bear this affliction? May they receive consolation from above, where alone it can be found at such times. I hope you may all have strength given you to bear it. I feel very anxious for you all, you know how

dear you are to me. I always think that my Remsen Aunties are a little nearer perfection that anyone else in the world. Partly because you are so good and lovable, and partly because you seem so much like my precious mother, who I know was almost without fault. 
We shall want to know how Aunt Sarah is. Hope she will improve fast. Lizzie and the children, with Aunt Louisa came last Tuesday. We are enjoying their company very much. Lizzie says to tell you that Anna is the best baby in the world. I am inclined to think she is too. She laughs a great deal, and very seldom cries. Her cheeks are as fat as little butterballs. I think her a remarkable pretty baby, much prettier than Claire used to be. Claire is quite a girl now. Almost a seven years old. She can read very well, and enjoys it.

She likes to romp? too, and is happy if she can get her Uncle John to frolic with her. She is chattering like a magpie now, so I can hardly keep ? ? together. Father enjoys them all so much. It seems so good to have our family together once more and ? Louisa here too.  She and father always thought so much of each other, they enjoy each others society once more very much. 
You asked me to tell you more about my eyes. I hardly know how much I have told or what is? say. It is so much easier to answer questions than to start in and describe any trouble. They trouble me the most if I try to read, or get them heated? in any way. The week after Apia? left I did all this work myself, thinking we should enjoy it so much better if be alone, but being over this store?

so much ? very bad for them, and they kept getting worse and worse until I was obliged to get a girl to come and help me. When they are bad I have such sharp pains shoot through them in the back part of the eye-ball, and can hardly hold them open. Sometimes it seems as though there was something slipping down back of one of them. The left eye is the worst. But the stranger part of it is that they look as well as they ever did.  When ? Louisa came she said "Why there is nothing the matter with your eyes".  I am very glad of this.  I never could stand "red eyes". But I feel quite anxious about them.  When they get tired they burn so, and shut up without any apology. I do nothing for them except bathe them in salt water. 
The oculist who seemed to understand them the best said there was inflamation fo the retina, and I

Hillsdale, Mich.
Oct. 3, 1881
Dear Sister Jennie
We were happy to receive your letter, and Hattie thinks she will write you today; so I will put in a few lines. Glad you have having pleasant company and a good time this summer.  I little thought when we made you that hurried visit three years ago, it would be so long before we should visit again. Hope Larch? is gaining, and will soon be much better.  John Eddy is quite persevering? about his education, and trust he will succeed in full. 
Our company are yet with with us. They are all well. Lizzie continues to improve, and now seem to be pretty

will. Anna? Claire? enjoys it here greatly. She is now nearly seven years old, strong and active. She and I take baby out to side mart? every day. Little Anna is one of the smartest, plumpest little ones you ever saw, hardly ever cries, but always so bright & cheery. She is about nine months now Sister? Thompson is also enjoying her visit, but will probably go back to New England in a week or two. Lizzie thinks of staying till after Thanksgiving. Hattie will finally go to Cincinnati Wed. of this week. Of course we shall be anxious till she returns. It is very mild here, with considerable rain of late. A letter from Johnny today. They are doing nicely. All moving? pleasantly in college with 375 students. Please write often.
With Much Love to you all,
J.J. Butler

Hillsdale, October 3rd
Dear Aunt Jennie
I will only write 
a little this morning, as I am very 
busy, but I am sure we ought to 
acknowledge your good letter.
I hop to go to Cincinnati day 
after tomorrow, if it is pleasant. 
I dread it a little, as I must go 
alone, but anything for the sake of 
my eyes, and I should need the 
help of Providence too, if I had 
ever so much human protection.
How I wish you could all come 
over here and spend this winter. 
We should enjoy it so much, 
but I suppose you would think 
it too far.  It will be so lonely 
for me after Lizzie and my Aunt 
are gone.  I am going to 
sing for one of the societies tonight. 
Just now a member of another 
society came to get me to sing

for them too.  I have [?] work to do 
today as our girl is washing, so I 
shall not be able to do anything 
towards packing until tomorrow. 
If I go Wednesday, I hope to get 
back by Saturday.  Claire takes 
a great deal of comfort with the 
locket you gave her.  She wears 
it every Sunday.  She enjoys going 
to church, very much.
How is Maggie's health now?  And 
Sarah Jane's?  Please give much 
love to them. I should have 
written them long before now, but 
for my eyes.  I do hope Aunt 
Sarah is feeling better.  Is Aunt 
Anna's health good now? 
You must all take care of 
yourselves.  I want to see you 
all very much.  It seems a 
long, long time since I visited 
you in N.Y.  Write soon please.
With much love
Hattie

Hillsdale, January 8th, 1882
Dear Aunt Jennie:
We have been very glad of the Lastale which you have sent us so frequently, and will try to be more fronted in writing ourselves.  We feel very amorous a back Aunt Sarah,

of her pure, unselfish character, which 
showed itself in every act and word, 
has made me want to be a better 
Christian, whether I have been one 
or not.  I long to see her dear face 
and talk with her once more.  God 
grant that I may, if it is His will. 
Father and I are getting along after 
our usual fashion.  That is not 
very wild or boisterous, you know, 
- at least as far as he is con-
cerned.  And I can't make much 
rumpus by myself.  He is at his 
classes from nine in the forenoon 
until twelve, and down town about 
an hour in the afternoon, so 
I have the house pretty much 
to myself, a considerable part 
of the time.  I am not taking music 
this winter, but trying to favour my 
eyes.  These long evenings would be 
much more pleasant if we could 
read aloud, part of the time, but 
of course that is impossible.

Father has to use his eyes in the 
daytime as much as they will bear. 
So we both welcome the length-
ening days.  Do you ever hear 
from Johnnie?  He wrote me last week 
that the thermometer had been 21 
below zero there,  The lowest it has 
been here was 2 below.  And the next 
day there were heavy rains!  A 
change in the weather is about all 
we can depend on.  As someone 
said he other day, those who like 
variety ought to be suited.  
Does John Eddie continue to take 
part in that "debating club"?  
If so, here are two questions that 
were given the Harvard students 
for discussion - 1st "Ought 
members of the Cabinet 
to be responsible for Congress?"  
2nd "Does the possession of a 
good memory afford any indi-
cation of the presence of absence 
of other mental powers."

I think I would like to belong to a 
debating club.  They must be very 
interesting as well as instructive.  
Wonder if girls couldn't carry them 
on as well as boys.  I suppose 
J.E. would say No. because a 
woman must always have the 
last word, and so there would be 
no end to the first discussion.  
It isn't so, though, is it?  
How is Aunt Mary's health now? 
I hope to have a letter from you 
when you get time for it.  Tell 
me how each one is, and how 
you are yourself.
I must send this to the office, 
and so write no more this time.  
Lizzie writes that Anna isn't 
very well, and Claire has been 
most sick.  Such a trying 
winter for everybody.  May our 
dear ones be mercifully spared 
to us.  With much love to all
Hattie

203 Brower St Ysilsnt, Michigan 
April 22nd, 2892
Dear Cousin,
I enclose the check for your trunk. I am sorry we couldn't have sent it so you can get it today, but when Holden was down to attend to it yesterday, he found that the dray-man had left the trunk down town. He spoke with him about it, and this morning found it there at the depot, all right. These draymen are a necessary evil, I suppose, and are a help to us in the exercise of patience (!) I hope the delay will not annoy you too much
Aunt Mary's letter was gladly received this morning, also a letter for you from  Lansing, which

I will forward.
We were sorry to hear about Aunt Anna's illness. I hope your (sic) not going there Wednesday was not the cause of it. It was a great comfort to have you here,  but I fear I did wrong to let you stay. I hope Aunt Anna is [infirming?} fast and will have nothing to put her back.
I am feeling as well today as yesterday , but much better than I was the first of the week. 
It looks very much like rain and I hope if it comes it will be soon, so I shall not get caught at the farther end of town in it, where our Ladies Aid Society meets this afternoon.
I shall be so glad of a rest from all this church work, even for a few days if it is so I can go to Hillsdale in May. I forgot

talk with you any more about that girl you spoke of at Herrill (?) Would you be willing to spare her from your church if we wanted her? And do you think she is still free to make an engagement? If you are willing, and think best, I would like to have you write to her and see what she would do.l I think from what you said it would be a very good change for us to get goods help, and we really ought to have it.
Please excuse this unsatisfactory little note. Eva's incessant little chatter has kept my thoughts in a whirl.
With much love to all, and an especial portion to dear Aunt Anna, (and another special portion to each of the others, including "that boy"
Affectionately , 
Hattie

Dear Cousin Eddie:

                                 I wish you would 

come where I am now. I am not in 
Bay View now. I am in Petoskey.
I wish you would come to Petoskey. 
We are in Mrs. Graves' house. 
I got a little basket, and I got a 
dolly. I got just one dolly. 
A lady gave me a new fan. The same 
lady that gave me the fan, gave me
some beads. A lady gave me some 
candy. I put a kiss on this letter. 
I like it here better than I do Bay View. 
I know something daisy? to tell you. 
I wish I was at Hillsdale and I 
wish I was in New York and every.
O
Kiss

where I had a banana to eat.
Fondly,
Eva
KISS

____  The Unelected Infant ____

An unelected infant, sighed its little breath.
And wandered through the darkness, along the shores of death.
Until the gates of Heaven agleam with pearl , it spied,
And ran to them and clung there and would not be denied.
Though still from earth came mutterings, "You cannot enter in,
Depart into Gehenna, you child of wrath and sin".
If last the gates were opened; a man with features mild
Stooped down and raised the weeping unelected child.
Immortal light thrilled softly down avenues of bliss,
As on the infant's forehead the spirit placed a kiss.
"Who are you, thus to hallow my unelected brow?"

"Dear child, my name was Calvin, but I see things better, now"
W. Y. Evangelish

{WRITTEN UPSIDE DOWN ON BOTTOM OF PAGE} 
Dear Eddie,
I enclose this poem for your
edification. We expect to stay here

for awhile now so if you write
after getting this please direct to Petoskey, Michigan.

Hattie

My dear cousin Eddie,
What can you have 
straight? of me all this time, for not an-
swering your two good letters? If I
could only use my eyes in fight evening,
you would have had several letters instead
of none, but ? days have been 
packed full and running over!
I cannot remember when I did write 
you last, or what I have told you and 
what I have not. Of course you
knew that Elisabeth went back to
Oberlin in September, and that
Clair was married the tenth of Oct.
I visited Elisabeth at Oberlin the 
week before we came up here, and
spent Sunday with her. Of course 
it was a great pleasure to me.
One of the best things was attending
Vesper service in [[. ____ ____ ____]]?
church  Sunday afternoon, and
hearing that wonderful vested

choir of 160 voices, sing. The Recessional,
"Abide with Me", moved me the most 
of any music I ever heard. It is
worth a great deal to Elisabeth to be
in the choir. We spent a few days
with Lizzie before coming up here.
and Claire was there one day.
We reached Charles---------? Thursday,
November 2, and our girls arrived

the next night. Holden had

the house all engaged, so we could
begin settling as soon as they could
be brought up. We have a very
pleasant home, though it is not
a parsonage. The house faces the
East, and back of us is beautiful 
Lake Michigan. We are in what
is known as the North Terrace
and our house has "Pine Cliff
Cottage" over the door. Doesn't that
sound nice and summery, and
breezy, for December? The house
seems very warm however, but 
has to be heated with stoves. We
descend three flights of stairs from 
our back yard, and come upon
a fine white sandy beach ?
the sea shore, where the waves
come surging up like the Ocean.

and the water seems boundless. There is an evergreen grove back of the house which breaks the sound. How I wish you could visit us here in the summer. Won't you be able to, this coming summer? Our church is not as large as the one at Hudson, but they pay more salary. The membership is about 1156-125? I think they pay $1100 [?] and have started out to pay in full every month. I hope they will be able to keep this up. We have a very pleasant house of worship; a frame building  decorated inside with a good lecture room which can be ? with the ? room, and a very good ? organ. There were 120 men in S.S. last Sunday. Dr E.E. Lassit (?) materialized since we came but they are making efforts to ?

it. The people are exceedingly friendly and cordial, and we have gained in home feeling, already. I confess though, that I was a little homesick at first. We seemed do far away from everyone, especially our dear little girl. But she will soon be coming home to us soon. 
Two weeks from next Thursday, ????? to have her here. She will have to stay all night in Grand Rapids, but she is coming ?????? with ? Porter, the president of the Y.W. C.A.in Oberlin, who lives twelve miles from here, so will be all right. Elizabeth was twenty years old last Tuesday. Can you realize it? The 
girl who used to say her name was "Edie Punter. She is taking both vocal and instrumental music this year. and also a course in Public School Music, so she will be fitted to teach. This will be her last year in Oberlin. We are so thankful we could send her these five [?] years. We were invited over to the next house for dinner on Thanksgiving Day. There was just one other family invited and we had a very pleasant time. At Holden's suggestion, the

Order of Morning Worship
Sunday, Nov. 14, 11:00
ORGAN PRELUDE
PROCESSIONAL -
CALL TO WORSHIP. (Congregation Seated)
Minister: The Lord is in his holy temple, let all the earth keep silence before Him.
People: Surely the Lord is in this place.
Minister: This is none other than the house of God.
People: And this is the gate of Heaven.
Minister: Let the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart
People: Be acceptable in Thy sight, O Lord, my strength and my Redeemer.
Minister: What shall I render unto the Lord for all His benefits toward me?
People: I will take the cup of salvation and call upon the name of the Lord.
Minister: I will pay my vows unto the Lord, yea, in the presence of all his people.
People: In the court of the Lord's house, in the midst of thee, O Jerusalen.
Unison: PRAISE YE THE LORD.
VENITE EXULTEMUS. (Congregation Standing)
Oh, come let us sing unto the Lord: Let us heartily rejoice in the strength of our salvation.
Let us come before His presence with thanksgiving And show ourselves glad in Him with psalms.
For the Lord is a great God; And a great King above all gods.
In His hands are all the corners of the earth; and the strength of the hills is His also.
The sea is His and He made it; And His hands prepared the dry land.
Oh, come, let us worship and fall down; And kneel before the Lord our Maker.
Glory be to the Father, and to the Son, And to the Holy Ghost;
As it was in the beginning, is now, and ever shall be World without end. AMEN, AMEN.
INVOCATION (Congregation Standing.)

HYMN No. 320
SCRIPTURE LESSON
ANTHEM
PRAYER

HYMN No. 693
SERMON
PRAYER

BENEDICTION
POSTLUDE

Church Notes
There will be a service at the Mission on Dowland St. this afternoon at 3:00 o'clock.
The Christian Endeavor Society will hold its meeting in the church parlor this evening at 6:15. Carl Hammond will lead.
The union service will be held in this church this evening at 7:00 o'clock. Sermon will be preached by Rev. I. J. Heizer, the Presbyterian pastor.
The Men's Personal Workers' League will meet Monday evening at 7:30 at the Dowland St. Mission.
The Ladies' Aid Society will meet in the church parlor Wednesday afternoon at 2:30.
Mid-week service Thursday evening at 7:30. The topic will be "Abraham's Obedience." Its promptness; its completeness; its reward. The call for a venturing faith today.
Friday evening the Junior Scouts will meet in the basement of the church at 7:00 o'clock.
Pithy sayings from addresses at the National Council:
Money is often the cheapest thing that a man can give. - Judge Coit.
You kneel down to pray for peace and you rise up to prepare for war. - Dr. Aked.
There are things which can be conserved only by dying for them. - G. A. Gordon.
Men will not always be ready to be cannon-food for King or Kaiser - Dr. Aked.
A good name is rather to be desired than a touring car. - Detroit version according to Schermerhorn. 
The church is the fundamental institution in the reconstruction of our social order. - H. A. Atkinson.
During the last three light decades we have been smoking the opium pip of evolution. - Dr. Gordon.
Every normal function of the body furnishes a meeting place between God and man. - Dr. R. G. Brooks.
A state superintendent is a "dehorned" bishop - "dehorned" so he can be a great pusher. - H. F. Schwartz.
If laziness - physical, intellectual, moral - is not original sin, it lies very close to the source. - H. C. King.
We can never repay the debt we owe to the veteran soldiers of the cross, but the church will never repudiate that debt. - C. S. Mills.
Everything that belongs to the spirit of love is sacred, and everything that belongs to the spirit of hate is secular. - Dr. R. G. Brooks.

PINE CLIFF COTTAGE
My dear Aunt Mary:
A letter received from Cousin Eddie a few days ago, told me of your accident, and now another from Cousin Clara gives me more particulars. We were so very much grieved to hear of it. and I expected to write you at once on hearing of it, but my poor eyes, and its seaseless demands
